The News-Leader,
Richmond, Va.
Sept. 15. 1925
Telephone Randolph 7
THE
__________________________________________________
div1.p:
DR. HENRY CARTER'S brave, unselfish life was one that inspired
men long before it ended yesterday.

This Virginian was heir to a great name and to as fine an an-
cestry as any American possesses, but he never played the aristocrat
or wasted his time among tombs. Entering the public health ser-
vice as soon as he was graduated from medical college, he plunged
immediately into the study of tropical diseases, notably yellow fever
and malaria.

That was in 1879---fourteen years before SIR RONALD ROSS
began his malarial investigations and twenty years before the first
American experiments in yellow-fever control in Cuba. PASTEUR
was then in the fullness of his labors, LISTER'S results were just be-
ing accepted, and the first real bacteriological research ever under-
taken in America was about to be inaugurated by a young man of
28, WILLIAM H. WELCH by name, who was just returning from
Germany. WALTER REED was 27 and finding life none too rosy for
an assistant surgeon, ranking first lieutenant, U. S. A. That very
year WILLIAM C. GORGAS, aged 24, entered on his duties as interne
at Bellevue Hospital.

From the hour he saw his first case of yellow fever until the
moment of his death, probably not a day passed that DR. CARTER
did not think of that disease or of that other malady carried by the
mosquito, the dread malaria, the “chills and fever” of the South. He
put into his work every energy of his spirit. Nothing else, except
his duty to his family and to his Maker, ever counted with him. If
the trail of yellow fever and malaria lay through the media and
among the test tubes of a central laboratory, he would work there,
but if it carried him through Panama jungles, or along the oozing
river-bottoms of South America, or into swamps of his own Virginia
whence the insect long ago had driven man, he did not hesitate to
follow. He was oblivious alike to the convenience of the laboratory
and to the hardships of field surveys, and for the same reason: he
never thought about himself, but always and only about his work.
He had attained, as few men ever do, to the objective state of
mind.

Because he was absorbed in the battle, he never considered the
rewards of victory. Had he been mindful of his own fame, even of
his own legitimate interests, he might easily have established his
claim to much of the credit for the epochal results of the Cuban ex-
periments and for the transformation of the canal zone. But he
had little time and surely no mind for such things. Let men give
REED and CARROLL and their colleagues all praise for establishing
the cause of yellow fever. Let GORGAS' be the name the world
always remembered when the epic of the conquest of Panama was
recited. For his part, the foe was mobilized on so many frontiers
and lurked, like scattered partisans, in so many marshes, that he
could never come off the fighting line to dispute about honors.

It was so to the last. He returned from South America some
years ago completely broken by fever, but he would not relax. His
recovery was slow because, as his friends believed, he had overtaxed
his strength by his personal exertions in keeping malaria from the
precincts of the marine camp at Quantico during the war. Chained
at last, he turned to writing a biography of DR. GORGAS, and as
the end drew on, he battled for a few more weeks of breath--not to
live but to write!

He was, in the bulk and in the lasting results of his achieve-
ments, one of the three or four more distinguished native Virginians
alive in 1925, and in the devotion of his spirit he was one of that
matchless company of great scientists whom the nineteenth century
may claim as its sons, but to whom every age will be debtors.

It is to such a life as this--and they are being spent in service
everywhere--that the idealist rejoices to turn when his own faith is
failing and when the lamp of his own endeavor begins to flicker. For
there is no life that so surely strengthens the soul of man as a life
reflecting the love that “seeketh not its own.”
